title: NSW leads new states push to rekindle asset recycling
text:
He said the capacity to do more lay with so-called tier two and tier three projects, defined as worth less than $50 million, and this was where the federal government could step in.

"If you look at the forward estimates in the federal budget, there's not a lot coming to Victoria,'' he said.

Mr Perrottet agreed with Mr Pallas. "There's a much greater capacity in the minor infrastructure projects,'' he said.

Asset recycling

But, he added, over the longer term, the Commonwealth needed to play a bigger role in funding larger projects and leave the smaller projects to the states because the states were much better placed to identify areas of need.

On Thursday, the state Treasurers will meet among themselves and Mr Perrottet said he would seek support for the states, as a collective, to push federal Treasurer Josh Frydenberg to reintroduce asset recycling.

The initiative was first introduced by then-treasurer Joe Hockey in 2014 and involved the Commonwealth paying 15 per cent of the cost of an infrastructure project from a $5 billion fund if the state was funding it from the proceeds of an asset privatisation.

Mr Perrottet made the case to Mr Frydenberg back in July but was rebuffed. It is understood the Commonwealth was wary about the threat to its promised budget surplus.

NSW is already investigating leasing out its forestry corporation, a softwood plantation business, as part of a plan for more asset sell-offs to pay for infrastructure projects.

'Our success is their success'

It is also looking at selling its remaining 49 per cent share of the WestConnex road project.

"The federal government can play an important role, whether it's asset recycling or other reform opportunities, when they put money in the table,'' he said.

"If they were to give us a greater contribution to major projects, that would unlock funds for minor projects.

"We're all looking at ways to grow the economy. Our success is their success.''

Mr Pallas said Victoria supported NSW's push to bring back asset recycling but added it was of questionable benefit to Victoria because it had very few assets left to sell.

He said with the pressures on the economy caused by global factors, he agreed with Reserve Bank governor Philip Lowe that the Commonwealth needs to do more in terms of stimulus.

"We'll hold our nerve and continue our investment,'' he said.
description: NSW and Victoria say Canberra has a greater capacity to fast-track infrastructure spending.
